tweet: It can be either perfect or awesome. I would rather have it awesome.

Compassionate, high-quality, cost-effective care thrives in institutions whose members embrace the culture of collegiality, generosity, and excellence. None of this conflicts with fiscal discipline and remaining competitive.

#MayoMindfulness: @AmitSoodMD says, "Research shows #laughter provides a good physical workout, generates mental relaxation, lowers blood pressure and pain, and even improves immunity."  https://mayocl.in/2maoeJj  pic.twitter.com/in6lXZY5fU
Hunting for joy in the tiniest of moments while remaining anchored in our values is our hope to thrive - until the world around us wakes up to, and embodies the wisdom of compassion.

Feeling loved & making a difference in someone’s life helps us feel worthy. Loneliness and invasion of technology is hurting both. The solution: think of those who care about you, show others you care, and resolve that tomorrow you’ll truly focus on the person behind the numbers.

When external expectations change faster than our ability to adapt and deliver, we get overwhelmed. Best to preemptively set your own expectations based on your capacity and preference, and help others reset expectations of you, so no one is disappointed or burnt out in the end.

Research shows that in an average medical office, physician feels much less personally accomplished than the support staff. With bulk of the time spent with EMR, a health care provider’s work today lacks meaning & joy. Lack of meaning predisposes to suboptimal high-cost care.
Sometimes the adversity of today might save us from a catastrophe of tomorrow. Thinking such would not push the pain away but will help you better endure today’s pain, if you are hurting.
An interview with @AmitSoodMD about #digitalwellness.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DORQeh3ydzI&feature=youtu.be … @Global_GWS

Repeatedly blaming the ‘outside forces’ creates ‘external locus of control’ that makes us feel powerless, increases stress, and burnout. Feeling empowered to act, take control, and influence events (i.e. internal locus of control) enhances wellbeing.
An ideal approach to burnout is to empower the individuals with resilience and collectively work to improve the system, acknowledging its strengths and weaknesses.

May the 4th bring you courage and hope, the freedom to pursue happiness, say No, disagree, honor the truth, value differences, love, help the vulnerable, be vulnerable, and wake up to the infinitely precious gift of being full alive.

Speech is brain food. Your brain gets rewired by the words it hears. Be very careful in selecting the people who receive your attention and your trust. Hope you like this video. https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=_hsLwXaU3Eg …
History will judge us by the difference we make in the everyday lives of children. - Nelson Mandela
Crying can help us emotionally as well as physically. Delighted to share this short video with you. https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=T6dgQTlQrEk …

Physician burnout happens from a combination of cognitive overload & emotional depletion in a health system dominated by business norm. We need an integrated approach that embraces the two poles of individual & organizational strategies. Arguing this vs. that is a waste of time.

Children raised in poverty have smaller memory area of the brain (hippocampus). This effect can be minimized by quality of caregiving. We must not let material poverty translate into emotional poverty. That is the hope to break the poverty cycle.  https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/24165922/ …
Happy father’s day! The best thing we dads can do for our children is to love their mom and show it.

There is a difference between life satisfaction & moment to moment happiness. Success/fame help us feel accomplished but may not give lasting happiness since we adapt to the gains. This leaves us vulnerable. Nurturing relationships, strong purpose, gratitude & faith can all help.
Sometimes it helps to look at the yard with more weeds to enjoy yours with fewer. (Scientists call this downward social comparison - which correlates with happiness)

We don’t need stellar new technologies to create a happier world. We just need to harness the power of gratitude and compassion.
May you and I find freedom from our negative predispositions. May we truly value our freedom, for it is precious, and lead our lives to help others, who might not be so lucky.

Just saw two teenagers walking on a train track, buried in their smartphone. We as parents must collectively take action so we don’t lose our children to technology. Normalizing this behavior is dangerous.
So so so sad to see the innocent children in our country/society losing their lives. We must do more.

Forgiveness doesn’t mean you don’t expect good behavior in the future. In fact forgiveness coupled with expectations that others will change leads to better outcomes compared with unconditional forgiveness.  https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/29708364/ …

Happy mother’s day. A dwelling where mothers are loved, respected, and revered, becomes a home. Every other place is just a rental property. We must resolve to convert all rental properties into homes on this planet.

Only when we face obstacles do we zoom out to see the big picture. Appreciating and accepting the obstacles you have to negotiate today (at least some of them) will help you overcome them while growing your wisdom.  https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/21875228/ …

Research shows counting previous kind actions makes us happier. It also helps us become kinder. So when you have a moment today, try to recall your last two kind actions. It will lift your world, at least a tiny bit.  http://ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/17356 …

As important as being blessed is to know how blessed we are. A deep breath, taste of water, the spring around us, sunshine, and our ability to experience them all - these are infinitely precious blessings.

When we are kind to people, they, without knowing, start embodying our behaviors (called behavioral mimicry). This is another good reason to be kind to children and others who we wish to motivate into making better choices.  https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/25286071/ …

Conflicts are times of great opportunity when you can show your caring/love for others by trying to fully understand their perspective. Such an approach results in conflicts strengthening, and not weakening your relationships - both at home and at work.  https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/26523997/ …

Authenticity is perhaps more important than positivity. Feeling emotions that are in sync with the lived experiences is more helpful than suppressing emotions or forcing positive emotions. Having said that, sustained deep negative emotions are unhelpful.

Focusing on our own pain keeps us in the pain, prolonging the agony. Focusing on others’ pain, with an intention to heal, fosters healing - of others and self. A good way to heal yourself is to heal someone else.

The never-ending pursuit of happiness can push away happiness by creating time pressure. Contentment with the present while pursuing altruistic meaning offers a much healthier alternative. I am enough and I have enough - is a powerful mantra.  https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/29524087/ …

Being easily moved to tears can help your immunity. In patients with rheumatoid arthritis, those who cried more to emotional scenes had better control of disease on follow up. So don’t be embarrassed if you tear up easy. You are helping your immune system.  https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/14611110/ …

Interesting research shows your brain waves start mirroring the brain waves of the person you are listening to. Carefully pick the people you allow to influence your brain waves.  https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/20660768/ …
Seeing the light in others will help you see the light within yourself.

Brain (cognitive) overload is here to stay. The key is to minimize the emotional cost of cognitive overload. Resilience, mindfulness, meaning, physical fitness, relationships, faith - all can help. Perhaps a little bit of all might create the ideal mix.

Brain (cognitive) overload is here to stay. The key is to decrease the emotional cost of cognitive load. Resilience, mindfulness, physical fitness, faith, meaning, relationships - all can help. Perhaps the best solution is a little bit of each of these.
Frontage roads are sometimes faster than highways because even though highways have higher speed limits, they also have more traffic jams. Perhaps the same is true of life.

If my right & left hands see each other as different, compete, & feel discriminated by each other, then the one suffering is me. Our focus on our differences hurts our children. Our unity and shared purpose is essential for us to build a better world for our little ones.

Resilience is becoming a driver of the solution, instead of remaining a victim of the problem. Personal resilience helps you find effective solutions for the chaos instead of accepting the unacceptable status quo. Every single transformational leader was/is a model of resilience.

Healthcare is using knowledge and technology to deliver compassion. Healthcare systems and their regulators organized around this focus (and not profits) will engender much lower burnout in its employees.

Today evening, gift five minutes of authentic undivided attention to someone in your life who deserves that attention but isn’t getting it.
In your darkest moments you may feel like you are a victim. You can't stop yourself from going there. But you choose not to stay there.

If we are privileged to be grateful then we have responsibility to be compassionate.

To outdo the competition,most professions are now becoming high-touch professions. Employees have to deliver compassion while the system demands productivity-a recipe for burnout. Improving operational efficiency, readjusting expectations & enhancing resilience are few solutions.
Filling your eyes with gratitude and compassion, finding magic in your loved one’s eyes, is finding life. If that isn’t mindfulness, I don’t know what is.

Amidst chaos, create your own bubble of peace, energy, values, hope, and courage, in which you and your love thrives...just as our earth thrives in its bubble of air - our atmosphere - while floating in infinite expanse of cold, lifeless space. You have a choice.

It is near impossible to feel bad about ourselves during moments we are wishing others well.
Plan for the long term, live for the short term. Make the most of this evening with your loved ones and friends.

Research shows feeling unforgiven by others increases our risk of depression. The solution: Self-forgiveness. While we don’t have control over what others think of us, the greater our ability to forgive ourselves, the more we are protected from those who judge us.

In our darkest moments we lose hope, assume we are a victim, get caught in our own prison. Many of us are biologically or situationally predisposed to go there. But we can choose not to stay there - by helping ourselves, taking help from others, and finding refuge in faith. #Hope

We do not need to feel real upbeat all the time to be healthy and productive. If the situation demands you to feel a little down, it’s OK to feel that way instead of forcing a PanAm smile. Research shows forcing happiness on yourself will make you unhappy.
Best to be proactive about implementing forgiveness so you have lots of time for gratitude and love.
Crying is our way of healing. Sometimes the best laughs come only after the heart is emptied of tears.
It is possible that the realities may not match our hopes. Perhaps it is better to prepare for and accept that disappointment, than not hope at all.

Total lack of fear/hurts/anger could be a sign of brain damage. A healthy brain converts fear into action (courage), hurts into meaning (wisdom), anger into compassion (love). A healthy brain has it all - a tiny room for fear, hurts & anger; a big hall for courage, wisdom & love.
